citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There was one white tailed deer that had a pink area of missing hair on the left side of its neck approximately an inch wide
and 5 inches long. The facility representative reported that they had not noticed the missing hair but there had been some
fencing work done in the preceding days and the deer may have stuck its head through the fence.
Failure to adequately observe animals can lead to illness and injuries not being noticed or treated. Lack of treatment may
result in a minor problem becoming more severe.
Daily observations of all animals must be done to assess their health and wellbeing.

There has been no complete veterinary exams for the adults dogs in the kennel since February 2023. There were no
exams scheduled at the time of inspection. Veterinary exams are required to protect the health and wellbeing of the dogs.
A complete physical exam from head to tail of each dog by the attending veterinarian is required not less then once every
12 months.
Correction Date: May 24th, 2024

There are no records of adult dogs receiving rabies, parvovirus or distemper vaccines since February of 2023. The facility
representative reported that he did not think vaccines were due till May but could not remember when they were last
given. The program of veterinary care requires annual vaccination for parvovirus and distemper and latest rabies vaccines
that were given were 1 year vaccines.
Vaccination is important in protection from contagious diseases.
All dogs must be vaccinated in accordance with the schedule approved by the attending veterinarian.
Correction Date: May 24th, 2024

The enclosure for the spider monkey was 71 inches tall. Spider monkeys are a brachiating species and require enough
space to exhibit species typical behavior in order to ensure their physical and behavioral wellbeing. The spider monkey
should be provided with 25.1 square feet of floor space that is 84 inches in height in order to meet the minimum required
space per the regulations.

-The wire fence on the west side of the shelter in the fallow deer pasture was folded over and parts of it were broken
leading to there being sharp protruding points. Sharp points can lead to injury of animals and the folded over fence
increases the risk that animals could escape the enclosure.
-There were two approximately two foot square sections of wire panel fencing laying in the mud in the pen with the pig.
Loose fencing on the ground of an enclosure presents of risk of injury and entrapment.
-The pen with two foxes, and the facility representative reported that he expect kits soon as well, contained an
approximately two and a half foot triangular area that had up to a one foot deep erosion of dirt under the wire bottom of
the cage. The water dish for the enclosure is near the edge of this area. This area has a large risk of limb entrapment for
the adult foxes and more so once there are young foxes in the enclosure.
Housing facilities must be constructed and maintained in good repair to protect animals from injury and to contain
animals.

-There was a large fecal pile directly outside the shelter of the 14 goats and 1 alpaca. The bedding in the shelter was wet
throughout and soiled with feces.
-The shelter of the two raccoons had a large buildup of feces in the corner. The licensee reported that he planned to clean
it prior to opening to the public at the beginning of May.
-The enclosure containing one fox had fecal buildup on the ground and a disintegrating piece of carpet partly in the
ground.
Insufficient cleaning can lead to disease hazards, insects, pest and odors.
Excreta shall be removed from the primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals
therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors.
Correction date: April 19th, 2024

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
There was an incomplete written environmental enrichment plan for the birds. The plan provided was a copy of the USDA
regulations and did not address the individual plans needed for the species of birds present at the facility. Insufficient
enrichment for birds can cause psychological distress to birds and can lead to aggression or self-injurious behavior. A
complete written enrichment plan must be established, approved by the attending veterinarian and be made available to
USDA inspectors.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:

Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).

3.13(a)(2)

The enclosure for the spider monkey was 71 inches tall. Spider monkeys are a brachiating species and require enough

3.125(a)  Repeat

-The wire fence on the west side of the shelter in the fallow deer pasture was folded over and parts of it were broken

3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation. 
-There was a large fecal pile directly outside the shelter of the 14 goats and 1 alpaca. The bedding in the shelter was wet 
throughout and soiled with feces.  
-The shelter of the two raccoons had a large buildup of feces in the corner. The licensee reported that he planned to clean

-The enclosure containing one fox had fecal buildup on the ground and a disintegrating piece of carpet partly in the

Insufficient cleaning can lead to disease hazards, insects, pest and odors.  
Excreta shall be removed from the primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals

Correction date: April 19th, 2024 
3.154  Repeat
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
There was an incomplete written environmental enrichment plan for the birds. The plan provided was a copy of the USDA 
regulations and did not address the individual plans needed for the species of birds present at the facility. Insufficient
